publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 101.17

seg.seg: (Guṇasaṃpada) says : “O proficient one! Precisely for this reason we will be ready now: when this virtuous king Sunetra rises as a Buddha in the world, then we will be his
(tire)less se(rvants). He can for sure be a refuge for us in sorrow.” Jñānasthita speaks: “O friend, do remember this: When this virtuous one was a king by the name of
Jñānasthite spricht: "O Freund, erinnere dich doch daran: Als dieser Tugendhafte ein König mit Namen Araṇemi war, auch da hat er eine überaus erstaunliche Sache verrichtet."
Jñānasthite says: "Friend, do remember this: when this virtuous one was king by the name of Araṇemi, then also he performed an exceedingly astonishing deed."
Araṇemi, he did an even more wondrous thing.” Guṇasaṃpada speaks: “O proficient one! ...
Guṇasaṃpada spricht: "Hochmögender, ... geruhe dich noch genauer an das gute Tun d[ies]es Königs Araṇemi zu erinnern!"
Guṇasaṃpada says: "Highly skilled [one], deign to remember more accurately the good deeds of [this] king Araṇemi!"
Deign to remember the good deed of that king Araṇemi more accurately!” Jñānasthita speaks: “With concentrated [lit. upraised] mind, with(out) ...
Please remember the good activity of king Araṇemi more carefully! (cf 99; 303)
listen to this Jāta(ka sec)tion! || [In the tune] riññäkte || Not long the time has gone. Then the pearl of mankind, the king Araṇemi tarried there in the
town of Aru(ṇāvatī). Adorned he was with the ornaments of the (virtue)s. 1. There, however, the king Araṇemi, [after] (the wish ?) for the dignity of a Buddha had arisen indeed ...

p.note: Introduction of the Araṇemi-Jātaka. According to 303, the beginning of the text can at least partially be reconstructed as follows with the help of b 1-2: “Thereupon the two Tuṣita-gods, Jñānasthita [and] Guṇasaṃpada appear. Jñānasthita speaks: ...”.

The text is continued immediately by Pelliot Ouïgour I, 13-67 (1-20). From the latter's line 42 on, there are two Tocharian versions available as well, yielding a somewhat longer piece of text: one in TA (), and one in TB ().
Recto of the leaf; the verso is lost.

49, fn. 1 and again Thomas in 234 restore s(nai nerke)nta "without hesitation" ("sinngemäß", i.e. "to that effect"), but we would not expect a plural form here (cf. sg. snai nerke in a 5). To be sure, the reading 〈nta〉 at the beginning of a4 is a more likely one in any case than 〈tta〉 (thus Sieg/Siegling), since there are very few TB words ending in -tta; snai, on the other hand, is certain because one can still see remains of the 〈n〉 below the 〈s〉.
This strophe of 10|11|10|11 syllables has an uneven cola division of 4/6 in 1a and 5/5 in 1c.

The reading [··]e and restoration to (āñmn)e by 17 (followed by Schmidt) is impossible: the sign after the lacuna is surely an anusvara ṃ, the remains of part of a consonant speak in favor of n; ñ must likewise be excluded.

list.item: a1 w[e]_ṣ_ṣ_a[ṃ] [c](··)p(·)mñ[e]ccu tus(·)ks(a) nai ñ[ak](·) ārw(·)r tāka_m\ ente se kr(·)nt[auna]tts(·) sunetre wal(·) [p](·)ñ(·)kt(·) ś[ai]ṣṣ[en](·) tsāṅka o_t\ cw(·) sp(·)(– – – – –) a2 _l_acci tāka_m\• mapi kca sū cämpan-m(·) laklene waste nestsi || jñānasthite we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ waṣama epiyac pi tu pkala_r\ ente se krent[au](– – –) a3 raṇemi ñemtsa walo ṣai o○t rano sū ololyesa ākteke wantare yamaṣa : || guṇasaṃpade we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ cämpamñeccu s[n](·)(– –) a4 nta ṣpakk anaiśai epiyac [ka]○latsi porcañña_r\ cwi araṇemiñ lānte krent yamalñe • || jñānasthite we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ sasāllaṣ palsko(– –) a5 wyakṣe_p\• _p_aklyau_ṣ\ cau jāta(– – –)ske • || riññäktesa || mā lauke kca _k_atkau sū preke [ste] • śāmñe naumye araṇemi walo tne • a[ru](– – –) a6 rīne _m_askīt_r_a • yaitu ṣai s[ū] – – – ṣṣeṃ tsaiñ[ñ]entsa 1 || om no [ña]ke se araṇe(– –)lo (–) [n](·)aṃ ka pañä_k[_t_a]ṃñe [p]erneś[c]ä (–)ṅkau (– – – –)

Introduction of the Araṇemi-Jātaka. According to [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 303, the beginning of the text can at least partially be reconstructed as follows with the help of [[A 344]] b 1-2: “Thereupon the two Tuṣita-gods, Jñānasthita [and] Guṇasaṃpada appear. Jñānasthita speaks: ...”.

The text is continued immediately by Pelliot Ouïgour I, 13-67 ([[Hamilton 1986]]: 1-20). From the latter's line 42 on, there are two Tocharian versions available as well, yielding a somewhat longer piece of text: one in TA ([[A 342]]), and one in TB ([[THT 79]]).

The translation basically follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 303.

a3-4. [[Krause and Thomas, TEB II]]: 49, fn. 1 and again Thomas in [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 234 restore s(nai nerke)nta "without hesitation" ("sinngemäß", i.e. "to that effect"), but we would not expect a plural form here (cf. sg. snai nerke in [[THT 100]] a 5). To be sure, the reading 〈nta〉 at the beginning of a4 is a more likely one in any case than 〈tta〉 (thus Sieg/Siegling), since there are very few TB words ending in -tta; snai, on the other hand, is certain because one can still see remains of the 〈n〉 below the 〈s〉.

a5-6. This strophe of 10|11|10|11 syllables has an uneven cola division of 4/6 in 1a and 5/5 in 1c.

a6. The reading [··]e and restoration to (āñmn)e by [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 17 (followed by Schmidt) is impossible: the sign after the lacuna is surely an anusvara ṃ, the remains of part of a consonant speak in favor of n; ñ must likewise be excluded.

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-3 (800-900)
Tamai-C14–

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
2 Friend, please remember it! (cf [[Couvreur 1954c]]: 99) 361
4 Please remember the good activity of king Araṇemi more carefully! (cf [[Couvreur 1954c]]: 99; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 303) 308

a3-4 Guṇasaṃpada spricht: "Hochmögender, ... geruhe dich noch genauer an das gute Tun d[ies]es Königs Araṇemi zu erinnern!" 100
Recto of the leaf; the verso is lost.

a1 weṣṣäṃ c(äm)p(a)mñeccu tus(ā)ks(a) nai ñak(e) ārw(e)r tākam ente se krentaunatstse|kr(e)ntaunatts(e) sunetre wal(o) p(a)ñ(ä)kt(e) śaiṣṣen(e) tsāṅka«ṃ» ot cw(i) sp(aktanīki) alāläcci|(alā)|läcci a2 tākam mapi kca su|sū cämpan-m(e) laklene waste nestsi || jñānasthite weṣṣäṃ waṣama epiyac pi tu pkalar ente se krentau(natstse) araṇemi|(a)|raṇemi a3 ñemtsa walo ṣai ot rano su|sū ololyesa ākteke wäntare|wantare yamaṣṣa|yamaṣa : || guṇasaṃpade weṣṣäṃ cämpamñeccu sn(ai) (– –) a4 nta ṣpak|ṣpakk anaiśai epiyac kalatsi porcaññar cwi araṇemiñ lānte krent yamalñe • || jñānasthite weṣṣäṃ sasālaṣ|sasāllaṣ palsko(sa snai) a5 wyakṣep päklyauṣ cau jāta(käṣṣe me)ske • || riññäktesa || # mā lauke kca ; kätkau su|sū preke ste • #1a śāmñe naumiye|naumye ; araṇemi , walo tane|tne • #1b aru(ṇāvati) ; a6 rīne mäskītär|mäskīträ • #1c yaitu ṣai su|sū ; (krentauna)ṣṣeṃ , tsaiññentsa 1 || #1d omp|om no ñake se araṇe(mi wa)lo (–)n(·)aṃ ka pañäktäññe|pañäktäṃñe perneśc|perneścä (tsä)ṅkau – – – –

a1 (Guṇasaṃpada) says : “O proficient one! Precisely for this reason we will be ready now: when this virtuous king Sunetra rises as a Buddha in the world, then we will be his a2 (tire)less se(rvants). He can for sure be a refuge for us in sorrow.” Jñānasthita speaks: “O friend, do remember this: When this virtuous one was a king by the name of a3 Araṇemi, he did an even more wondrous thing.” Guṇasaṃpada speaks: “O proficient one! ... a4 Deign to remember the good deed of that king Araṇemi more accurately!” Jñānasthita speaks: “With concentrated [lit. upraised] mind, with(out) ... a5 listen to this Jāta(ka sec)tion! || [In the tune] riññäkte || Not long the time has gone. Then the pearl of mankind, the king Araṇemi tarried there in the a6 town of Aru(ṇāvatī). Adorned he was with the ornaments of the (virtue)s. 1. There, however, the king Araṇemi, [after] (the wish ?) for the dignity of a Buddha had arisen indeed ...
